Norway.description: Norway's Government Pension Fund Global (sovereign wealth fund) now exceeds $2 trillion, equivalent to $385,000 per citizen. Built from oil revenues since 1990.
Norway.relevance: Model for Scotland's proposed Wealth Fund

Norwegian.description: Norway's Government Pension Fund Global now exceeds $2 trillion, equivalent to $385,000 per citizen.
Norwegian.relevance: Model for Scotland's proposed Wealth Fund

Estonia.description: Population 1.3 million. World's most advanced digital government - 99% of public services accessible online 24/7. Digital ID, transparent government spending.
Estonia.relevance: Model for Scotland's digital democracy reforms

ScotWind.description: Scotland's offshore wind leasing round. Raised £700m in option fees alone. Adds 28 GW capacity to Scotland's renewable energy potential.
ScotWind.relevance: Key revenue source for proposed Scottish Wealth Fund

Crown Estate Scotland.description: Manages seabed leases for offshore wind. Current revenues ~£100m/year, projected to rise to £1-2bn with full development.
Crown Estate Scotland.relevance: Revenue source for Scottish Wealth Fund

Land Value Tax.description: Tax on land value rather than property or income. Would replace Council Tax. 60-70% of Scottish households would pay nothing. Revenue estimate: £2-5bn annually.
Land Value Tax.relevance: Key funding mechanism - shifts tax from workers to wealth

LVT.description: Land Value Tax - tax on land value rather than property. Would replace Council Tax. 60-70% of households pay nothing.
LVT.relevance: Key funding mechanism - shifts tax from workers to wealth

Danish.description: Denmark uses land value taxation and has universal childcare. 1.4% of GDP spent on early childhood. Higher workforce participation and birth rates than UK.
Danish.relevance: Model for land tax and childcare policies

Denmark.description: Denmark uses land value taxation and has universal childcare. 1.4% of GDP spent on early childhood.
Denmark.relevance: Model for land tax and childcare policies

Sweden.description: Universal childcare since the 1970s. Female workforce participation 80% vs UK's 72%. For every £1 spent on early years, £2-4 returns to the economy.

Iceland.description: Four-day week trials 2015-2019 with 2,500 workers showed productivity maintained or improved. Now 86% of workers have reduced hours or right to negotiate them.

Icelandic.description: Iceland's 2015-2019 four-day week trials showed productivity maintained. 86% now have reduced hours or right to negotiate them.

Switzerland.description: Life sciences sector contributes 5.7% of GDP and 30% of exports - over £80 billion annually. Model for 'science superpower' strategy.
Switzerland.relevance: Model for life sciences export strategy

Israel.description: 1,600 life sciences companies, attracts over £1 billion in biotech investment annually despite similar population to Scotland. Yozma program invested $100m, catalysed $10bn+ VC industry.

433 landowners.description: 433 landowners control half of Scotland's private rural land. Many inherited it, many pay little tax. Land Value Tax would generate £300-500m annually from large estates.

six billionaires.description: Six billionaires own 90% of UK print media: The Sun, Times, Telegraph, Mail, Express. Most are non-domiciled for tax. Would pay millions more under Land Value Tax.
six billionaires.relevance: Explains media opposition to these policies

Rupert Murdoch.description: Owner of News UK (The Sun, The Times). Non-domiciled for UK tax purposes. Estimated UK land holdings would face significant LVT liability.
Rupert Murdoch.relevance: Major media owner opposing land/wealth taxes

BBC.description: Licence fee set by Westminster. Board appointed by UK government. Over 80% of staff based in England, only 7% in Scotland. UWS study found 2014 referendum coverage favoured No 3:2.
BBC.relevance: Structural bias toward maintaining UK status quo

Reform UK.description: Three-quarters of funding from just three wealthy men. Over half of donations from people with homes in low-tax jurisdictions or offshore interests. Leaders include Farage (Dulwich College, City trader) and Tice (property developer, £40m).
Reform UK.funding_source: Hedge funds, property developers, offshore financiers
Reform UK.relevance: Example of wealthy interests funding 'anti-establishment' politics

Nigel Farage.description: Leader of Reform UK. Attended Dulwich College (£22k/year fees). Former City commodities trader. Party funded primarily by three wealthy donors with offshore interests.
Nigel Farage.relevance: Presents as anti-establishment while serving wealthy interests

Richard Tice.description: Reform UK chairman. Property developer worth £40 million. Grandfather was one of Britain's biggest property tycoons. Has claimed 'no evidence' CO2 causes climate change.
Richard Tice.relevance: Would pay significantly more under Land Value Tax

Institute of Economic Affairs.description: Refuses to disclose donors. Regularly quoted as 'independent' while promoting policies benefiting corporations. Opposes land value taxation and wealth taxes.
Institute of Economic Affairs.funding_source: Undisclosed - linked to fossil fuel and corporate interests
Institute of Economic Affairs.relevance: Example of dark money influencing policy debate

Taxpayers' Alliance.description: Sounds grassroots but founded by political operatives and funded by wealthy individuals. Campaigns against taxes that would affect wealthy donors.

Adam Smith Institute.description: Free-market think tank. Presents as neutral expertise while pushing policies benefiting corporate funders. Opposes regulation and progressive taxation.

Roslin Institute.description: Created Dolly the sheep (1996). World leader in genetics, stem cell research, and animal health. Based at University of Edinburgh.

Edinburgh BioQuarter.description: One of UK's largest health innovation campuses, adjacent to Royal Infirmary. Major hub for life sciences commercialisation.

CRUK.description: Cancer Research UK Scotland Centre: 80+ research teams across Edinburgh and Glasgow. Focuses on cancers affecting Scots (lung, bowel, pancreatic).

Cancer Research UK.description: Scotland Centre has 80+ research teams across Edinburgh and Glasgow, focusing on cancers affecting Scots.
Cancer Research UK.relevance: Key research asset for life sciences strategy

£125 billion.description: Energy company profits on UK operations since energy crisis began (over £500bn globally). While household bills doubled, shareholders got rich.
£125 billion.relevance: Wealth that could fund cheaper Scottish energy

44,453.description: Number of homes in Scotland empty for 6+ months. Another 21,606 are second homes. Meanwhile, 10 local authorities have declared housing emergencies.

triple lock.description: State pension rises by highest of: inflation, wage growth, or 2.5%. Adds £12bn annually above wage indexation. Benefits current pensioners at expense of future generations.

Scotch whisky.description: Scotland's largest export: £5.4bn in 2024 (26% of all Scottish goods exports). 152 distilleries, 41,000 direct jobs. 70% of bottle price goes to tax. 22 million casks maturing.
Scotch whisky.relevance: Key industry requiring trade policy support

Scot2Ger.description: Proposed hydrogen pipeline from Scotland to Germany. Part of broader hydrogen export strategy to Germany, Netherlands, Belgium. Could support 300,000 jobs and £25bn GVA by 2045.
Scot2Ger.relevance: Key infrastructure for Wealth Fund revenue

H100 Fife.description: World's first 100% renewable hydrogen network. 300 homes heated by hydrogen from 5MW electrolyser. Demonstrator project for hydrogen heating.

Queens Quay Clydebank.description: UK's largest water-source heat pump district heating system. Heats 1,200 homes and businesses using water from the River Clyde.

Microsoft Japan.description: Reported 40% productivity increase during four-day week trial. Staff worked 20% less time but output increased.

New Zealand.description: Banned foreign non-residents from buying existing homes in 2018. Part of Wellbeing Economy Governments partnership alongside Scotland.

Canada.description: Implemented two-year foreign buyer ban (2023-2025) on residential property. Provincial Nominee Program allows regions to select immigrants based on local needs.
Canada.relevance: Models for housing policy and immigration

Singapore.description: Charges 60% stamp duty for foreign residential property buyers. Central Provident Fund provides retirement security through mandatory savings.
Singapore.relevance: Models for housing restrictions and wealth fund

GERS.description: Government Expenditure and Revenue Scotland. Shows £26.2bn deficit (11.6% GDP) but includes Scotland's share of UK debt interest, defence, reserved spending. Does not reflect independent Scotland's finances.
GERS.relevance: Often misused to argue against independence

Citizen's Dividend.description: Annual payment to every Scottish citizen from Wealth Fund returns. Projected: £500-1,000/year initially, £2,000-3,000/year by Year 20, potentially £1,000-1,500/person by 2045.

Minimum Income Guarantee.description: Scottish Government consultation (June 2025). Ensures no resident lives below poverty line. Simpler than current benefits, no cruel sanctions. Pathway to Universal Basic Income.

MIG.description: Minimum Income Guarantee - Scottish Government consultation ensuring no resident lives below poverty line. Pathway to UBI.

four-day week.description: 32 hours over 4 days at full pay. UK 2022 pilot: 61 companies, 56 continued. Staff reported less stress, company revenue stable or improved. Iceland trials: productivity maintained, 86% now have reduced hours.

Scottish Child Payment.description: Currently £26.70/week per eligible child. Proposal to double to £55/week by 2031. Helps lift children out of poverty.

Home Energy Scotland.description: Grants up to £7,500 for heat pumps + £7,500 for insulation (£9,000 each for rural homes). Interest-free loans for remaining costs. Free improvements for fuel-poor households.

ECO4.description: UK scheme providing 100% FREE heat pump, insulation and solar for eligible low-income households. Available now.
ECO4.relevance: Existing free retrofit for eligible households

Warmer Homes Scotland.description: £10,000+ of free home energy improvements for fuel-poor households. Part of Scotland's fuel poverty strategy.

National Housing Company.description: Proposed public body to build 20,000+ social homes annually. Would help cap housing costs at 25% of median income.

Scottish Wealth Fund.description: Proposed sovereign wealth fund modelled on Norway's. Funded by renewable energy revenues, seabed leases, hydrogen exports. Projected £100-200bn by 2045.

transmission charges.description: Scottish wind farms pay £5.54/MWh to connect to grid. Welsh wind farms get PAID £2.80/MWh. Punishes Scotland for being far from London despite generating clean energy UK needs.
transmission charges.relevance: Key barrier to cheap Scottish energy

grouse moors.description: Sporting estates producing no food, employing few people relative to size. Exist primarily for recreation of wealthy. Would pay 1.5-2% LVT annually (£450-600k/year for 20,000ha estate).
grouse moors.relevance: Key target for land value taxation

A9.description: Scotland's most dangerous trunk road (Perth to Inverness). Dualling promised by 2025, repeatedly delayed. Disproportionate fatal collisions on single-carriageway sections.

CalMac.description: Ferry operator serving Scottish islands. Ageing fleet causing delays and cancellations. Road Equivalent Tariff not applied to all routes, making island life expensive.

Road Equivalent Tariff.description: Prices ferry travel at roughly same cost per mile as driving. Applied to some routes but not all. Full RET would cut island travel costs dramatically.

RET.description: Road Equivalent Tariff - prices ferry travel at same cost per mile as driving. Would make island life economically viable.

Erasmus+.description: EU student exchange programme. 2,000+ Scottish students per year lost access after Brexit. Would be restored with EU/Single Market membership.

freedom of movement.description: EU right to live, work, study, retire anywhere in 27 countries. Lost after Brexit. Would be restored with EU membership or Single Market access.

WEGo.description: Wellbeing Economy Governments partnership. Founding members: Scotland, Iceland, New Zealand, Wales, Finland. Recognises GDP is poor measure of success.

Wellbeing Economy.description: Economic framework prioritising collective wellbeing over GDP growth. Scotland is founding member of WEGo alongside Iceland, New Zealand, Wales, Finland.
